document.title: AP®  U.S. History COURSE AND EXAM DESCRIPTION Effective Fall 2023

5D525DDBE0754C65AA5B5111C079BA69.description:
Following the attacks of September 11,
2001, U.S. foreign policy efforts focused on
fighting terrorism around the world.

63A2046675E948AD880B7DF53BC70A77.description:
The Reagan administration promoted an
interventionist foreign policy that continued
in later administrations, even after the end
of the Cold War.

597B0FEEE3D64B088C2AB92CE7E9A24C.description:
The end of the Cold War and new challenges to
U.S. leadership forced the nation to redefine its
foreign policy and role in the world.

00B109E0FD1A4858BDA422D9EF010184.description:
The U.S. population continued to undergo
demographic shifts that had significant
cultural and political consequences.

48F58DA3C08F4E65B457616FC061461F.description:
New developments in science and
technology enhanced the economy
and transformed society, while
manufacturing decreased.

C28F5A0511E245E694EFA3EFC2E395D2.description:
Moving into the 21st century, the nation
experienced significant technological,
economic, and demographic changes.

DF8E3F59DA88403CB8A43F99A26A243D.description:
Conservative beliefs regarding the need for
traditional social values and a reduced role
for government advanced in U.S. politics
after 1980.

3902BFFAD7D5451C99791EA71E24F09C.description:
A newly ascendant conservative movement
achieved several political and policy goals during
the 1980s and continued to strongly influence
public discourse in the following decades.

666AFB015AE84BFF86DC8BA2997B4509.description:
Explain the relative
significance of the effects
of change in the period
after 1980 on American
national identity.

48D4DFCE7AC642638E1909B58D0E4CB9.description:
Despite economic and foreign policy
challenges, the United States continued as the
world’s leading superpower in the 21st century.

040D52323555431192217377D932AED0.description:
Conflicts in the Middle East and concerns
about climate change led to debates over U.S.
dependence on fossil fuels and the impact of
economic consumption on the environment.

8DC610D9BC97439ABAFE0D78280B64B0.description:
The war on terrorism sought to improve
security within the United States but also
raised questions about the protection of civil
liberties and human rights.

F178D5BBA0A64C46BFC143DDA5E8F938.description:
In the wake of attacks on the World Trade
Center and the Pentagon in 2001, the United
States launched military efforts against
terrorism and lengthy, controversial conflicts in
Afghanistan and Iraq.

0A275AA847AF4D90BA6C6D17BC1FF5B1.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the domestic and
international challenges the
United States has faced in
the 21st century.

20DDEABA1EDA441CAC25D3AF7C9DA6C1.description:
International migration from Latin America
and Asia increased dramatically. The new
immigrants affected U.S. culture in many ways
and supplied the economy with an important
labor force.

EACB0E7821494B86AF9BD2983B2916F5.description:
After 1980, the political, economic, and cultural
influence of the American South and West
continued to increase as population shifted to
those areas.

B4C59992C50246BB98A0002E236F8D5B.description:
Explain the causes and effects
of domestic and international
migration over time.

F727C6135F264BE3AAFEE7761086A532.description:
Migration and
Immigration in the
1990s and 2000s

D5222238D0F7469CB994BAA7701ED28A.description:
Real wages stagnated for the working and
middle class amid growing economic inequality.

59EC67A20A944DAB8727B484283341E6.description:
Employment increased in service sectors
and decreased in manufacturing, and union
membership declined.

0516A599BCD8456A96DE3CC621D05568.description:
Technological innovations in computing,
digital mobile technology, and the internet
transformed daily life, increased access to
information, and led to new social behaviors
and networks.

BBF72F9F73FC4C08BA289C998533033D.description:
Economic productivity increased as
improvements in digital communications
enabled increased American participation in
worldwide economic opportunities.

423DE679A6724192BA361CE6D63F304C.description:
Explain the causes and effects
of economic and technological
change over time.

12B24B4379E34214AE56A3847DDA133F.description:
The end of the Cold War led to new diplomatic
relationships but also new U.S. military and
peacekeeping interventions, as well as
continued debates over the appropriate use
of American power in the world.

61790683F6F2486C9AD4CCFE25065C75.description:
Increased U.S. military spending, Reagan’s
diplomatic initiatives, and political changes
and economic problems in Eastern Europe and
the Soviet Union were all important in ending
the Cold War.

E8E99EDBE7254DE789F54835B3C7D878.description:
Reagan asserted U.S. opposition to communism
through speeches, diplomatic efforts, limited
military interventions, and a buildup of nuclear
and conventional weapons.

FF2EFB19F5B446ADA472AB6F98763EA5.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the end of the
Cold War and its legacy.

A1A3B1E691C64B609D02E94B94AE1A55.description:
The End of
the Cold War

BAFC38AD968C4A1D81C9AA493E08A4BC.description:
Intense political and cultural debates continued
over issues such as immigration policy,
diversity, gender roles, and family structures.

13E4586677184E00A5F22FF00E4E45E7.description:
Conservative beliefs regarding the need for
traditional social values and a reduced role for
government advanced in U.S. politics after 1980.

8BD6FDF1821A44BEB3A42A7F13D432E2.description:
Policy debates continued over free-trade
agreements, the scope of the government
social safety net, and calls to reform the
U.S. financial system.

4EF479DDC7F34C6FA7B8132F3A497E15.description:
Conservatives argued that liberal programs
were counterproductive in fighting poverty
and stimulating economic growth. Some
of their efforts to reduce the size and scope
of government met with inertia and liberal
opposition, as many programs remained
popular with voters.

EF1E409119DD4AD183BCC63C9032D33F.description:
Ronald Reagan’s victory in the presidential
election of 1980 represented an important
milestone, allowing conservatives to enact
significant tax cuts and continue the
deregulation of many industries.

DCC4B4F189A94A729CAC82E8152263AF.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of continuing policy
debates about the role of
the federal government
over time.

93DACD5AA0ED416F9088AFD99BDFF351.description:
Following the attacks of September 11,
2001, U.S. foreign policy efforts focused on
fighting terrorism around the world.

5829596878324C3B9B61967324706B05.description:
The Reagan administration promoted an
interventionist foreign policy that continued
in later administrations, even after the end
of the Cold War.

51AEE26FDDE541B5A200939A15560C39.description:
The end of the Cold War and new challenges to
U.S. leadership forced the nation to redefine its
foreign policy and role in the world.

A003B77B3FF5457F963A5C998C51E898.description:
The U.S. population continued to undergo
demographic shifts that had significant
cultural and political consequences.

8DA5725DADAA462A987C001609136AB2.description:
New developments in science and technology
enhanced the economy and transformed
society, while manufacturing decreased.

B210D21D9A0741C69F5B70AC08D764CB.description:
Moving into the 21st century, the nation
experienced significant technological,
economic, and demographic changes.

01DD2DDC63FA4D3FAC430A5976FC6F65.description:
Conservative beliefs regarding the need for
traditional social values and a reduced role
for government advanced in U.S. politics
after 1980.

B3F83BE5C6CF4F85BD6E0CD0E7E6C6AA.description:
A newly ascendant conservative movement
achieved several political and policy goals during
the 1980s and continued to strongly influence
public discourse in the following decades.

F3B76F63E40241FBB7B7DCBEAACE49C9.description:
Explain the context in which
the United States faced
international and domestic
challenges after 1980.

BEB83CB9F1AE45F9A3072889A5EB0B29.description:
New demographic and social
developments, along with anxieties over
the Cold War, changed U.S. culture and led
to significant political and moral debates
that sharply divided the nation.

7D74DA58C651446C886C030A15F9E7F7.description:
Rapid economic and social changes in
American society fostered a sense of
optimism in the postwar years.

70D92B3D6BB1446285375AB958A15DFF.description:
Postwar economic and demographic changes
had far-reaching consequences for American
society, politics, and culture.

779CD6D9D43B434799950339C46A9B4E.description:
Liberalism influenced postwar politics
and court decisions, but it came under
increasing attack from the left as well as
from a resurgent conservative movement.

01F1C988F2B84D5DBEE4844228A6B013.description:
Responding to social conditions and the
African American civil rights movement,
a variety of movements emerged that
focused on issues of identity, social justice,
and the environment.

B506E052C6BD449E99A3F6A09707F6B9.description:
Seeking to fulfill Reconstruction-era
promises, civil rights activists and political
leaders achieved some legal and political
successes in ending segregation, although
progress toward racial equality was slow.

CBB88711D8B942F2A3C930B2EF6CCFF2.description:
New movements for civil rights and liberal efforts
to expand the role of government generated a
range of political and cultural responses.

042278BB9F3E46B38047189CA598885E.description:
Cold War policies led to public debates
over the power of the federal government
and acceptable means for pursuing
international and domestic goals while
protecting civil liberties.

B49C45EB268F4B0690DFC37DA3DDDE48.description:
United States policymakers engaged in
a cold war with the authoritarian Soviet
Union, seeking to limit the growth of
Communist military power and ideological
influence, create a free-market global
economy, and build an international
security system.

9E97FCBBF7FF4C22946D3107AA3F4591.description:
The United States responded to an uncertain
and unstable postwar world by asserting
and working to maintain a position of global
leadership, with far-reaching domestic and
international consequences.

16FCB99ABE9D4DD2A5D652E979B61232.description:
Explain the extent to which
the events of the period
from 1945 to1980 reshaped
national identity.

52F1BBF5E36B4BC18404FA9F606FDFD5.description:
The rapid and substantial growth of evangelical
Christian churches and organizations was
accompanied by greater political and social
activism on the part of religious conservatives.

07CEC2A96A3D4905AF668442C4A55D3A.description:
Explain the effects of
the growth of religious
movements over the course
of the 20th century.

7CE3D689B27E4BB5A4E4CB8EE99EF7F1.description:
The 1970s saw growing clashes between
conservatives and liberals over social and cultural
issues, the power of the federal government,
race, and movements for greater individual rights.

83376FCA4E1B4201BA54762321A9012D.description:
Public confidence and trust in government’s
ability to solve social and economic problems
declined in the 1970s in the wake of economic
challenges, political scandals, and foreign
policy crises.

AB13F49BAD7C4C198107F3CF33A8F5F5.description:
In the 1960s, conservatives challenged liberal
laws and court decisions and perceived moral
and cultural decline, seeking to limit the role
of the federal government and enact more
assertive foreign policies.

FF6F70E12386484BB9344B8AFEE1F3D3.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of continuing policy
debates about the role of the
federal government over time.

5AF53C9D550D4D7AAA475A289C374515.description:
Environmental problems and accidents led to a
growing environmental movement that aimed
to use legislative and public efforts to combat
pollution and protect natural resources.
The federal government established new
environmental programs and regulations.

69A3EF51D02D4372A309326B98F9A232.description:
Ideological, military, and economic concerns
shaped U.S. involvement in the Middle East,
with several oil crises in the region eventually
sparking attempts at creating a national
energy policy.

948079322EFB4DBF8A6E2825B2A1EDEF.description:
Explain how and why policies
related to the environment
developed and changed from
1968 to 1980.

AEA3385827BB47818DF55B6AC61F8AF0.description:
The Environment and
Natural Resources
from 1968 to 1980

2DB31D2DAA3C4D7D8FF452D88FF7520D.description:
Young people who participated in the
counterculture of the 1960s rejected many of
the social, economic, and political values of
their parents’ generation, introduced greater
informality into U.S. culture, and advocated
changes in sexual norms.

EAB41307A1804D0A9980C674CA02D7B8.description:
Some groups on the left also rejected liberal
policies, arguing that political leaders did too
little to transform the racial and economic
status quo at home and pursued immoral
policies abroad.

30DDA72F95F74941ADB795945729F53B.description:
Although anti-communist foreign policy faced
little domestic opposition in previous years, the
Vietnam War inspired sizable and passionate
anti-war protests that became more numerous
as the war escalated and sometimes led
to violence.

2AB231D665294A2A9EBBB24DBE263562.description:
Explain how and why
opposition to existing policies
and values developed and
changed over the course of
the 20th century.

0396E454C8F64AEBA4D30878B0D94E07.description:
Feminists who participated in the
counterculture of the 1960s rejected many
of the social, economic, and political values
of their parents’ generation and advocated
changes in sexual norms.

3B3D602F489F4263B881B71ABF2A6DC6.description:
Feminist and LGBTQ+ activists mobilized
behind claims for legal, economic, and
social equality.

92E78706E97A4221A4D2E092510F3E9F.description:
Latino, American Indian, and Asian American
movements continued to demand social
and economic equality and a redress of
past injustices.

58B0873A9A1B495284607DEF582AD575.description:
Explain how and why various
groups responded to calls for
the expansion of civil rights
from 1960 to 1980.

0CF5A856FA3C420DA45518E0030C85F3.description:
A series of Supreme Court decisions expanded
civil rights and individual liberties.

AA5710DB8A894A048958D4444EA2D5EB.description:
The three branches of the federal government
used measures including the Civil Rights Act of
1964 to promote greater racial equality.

A99A04BA097945B7B080E89EE18141FF.description:
Explain the various ways in
which the federal government
responded to the calls for the
expansion of civil rights.

7FFE71C2C324407E9C4A771A3563C0EB.description:
Continuing resistance slowed efforts at
desegregation, sparking social and political
unrest across the nation. Debates among civil
rights activists over the efficacy of nonviolence
increased after 1965.

8B738211962E4167B63CA01282767445.description:
During and after World War II, civil rights
activists and leaders, most notably Martin
Luther King Jr., combated racial discrimination
utilizing a variety of strategies, including legal
challenges, direct action, and nonviolent
protest tactics.

D93E3D8B5D594BB99C1C3564D8B9E0FE.description:
Explain how and why various
groups responded to calls for
the expansion of civil rights
from 1960 to 1980.

DBC3A9BDFEC140999188238074365191.description:
The African
American Civil Rights
Movement (1960s)

884E3FB942824498AC5A551C1FCCE5B0.description:
Immigrants from around the world sought
access to the political, social, and economic
opportunities in the United States, especially
after the passage of new immigration laws
in 1965.

888FB16513554793AF592B1676E93912.description:
Explain the continuities and
changes in immigration
patterns over time.

24C3550269CA4154A6F95561BB0A3965.description:
Liberal ideas found expression in Lyndon
Johnson’s Great Society, which attempted to
use federal legislation and programs to end
racial discrimination, eliminate poverty, and
address other social issues.

5E01082624AA4B469DD08BFD2960B256.description:
Liberalism, based on anti-communism abroad
and a firm belief in the efficacy of government
power to achieve social goals at home, reached a
high point of political influence by the mid-1960s.

9E1E81AECFD542828E0974043386A8B7.description:
Despite an overall affluence in postwar
America, advocates raised concerns about the
prevalence and persistence of poverty as a
national problem.

7F504317C2DC4F5DAE75E58CDD3C3710.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of continuing policy
debates about the role of
the federal government
over time.

2BDA837B8C4941A7A50A4874FDDD7175.description:
Americans debated the appropriate power of
the executive branch in conducting foreign and
military policy.

0199B87484B44E7EA73CB16FF51EC8D7.description:
Postwar decolonization and the emergence
of powerful nationalist movements in Asia
led both sides in the Cold War to seek
allies among new nations, many of which
remained nonaligned.

94D5FA97467842A8857BEBC733BD69E0.description:
Concerned by expansionist Communist
ideology and Soviet repression, the United
States sought to contain communism through
a variety of measures, including major military
engagements in Vietnam.

DA1FDD58CAED492486D916E1A8D83C5E.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the Vietnam War.

A0DD5DE602F54D368C042297E8B1381D.description:
Postwar decolonization and the emergence
of powerful nationalist movements in Africa
and the Middle East led both sides in the Cold
War to seek allies among new nations, many of
which remained nonaligned.

E1BC93E61FD94B6DBC6BDF5A36BE936C.description:
Americans debated the merits of a large nuclear
arsenal and the military–industrial complex.

E7E003BEC6BB45C0B886CD9FE1F3CD37.description:
Cold War competition extended to Latin
America, where the United States supported
non-Communist regimes that had varying
levels of commitment to democracy.

8AC7C69FC8F044A79D1443618A158DDC.description:
Explain the various military
and diplomatic responses to
international developments
over time.

372B02FC2EF84363834D0960E002CA2C.description:
The three branches of the federal government
used measures including desegregation of the
armed services and Brown v. Board of Education
(1954) to promote greater racial equality.

610D85B3268A4914A320254CA8DBF38A.description:
Seeking to fulfill Reconstruction-era promises,
civil rights activists and political leaders
achieved some legal and political successes in
ending segregation, although progress toward
racial equality was slow.

85CD0F5E22DA46DA980A7A707328D062.description:
Explain how and why the
civil rights movements
developed and expanded
from 1945 to 1960.

06F969C0BA654DF187604049B92DC7D8.description:
Early Steps in the
Civil Rights Movement
(1940s and 1950s)

A0988E26B10B421EBEEED0422567CAD6.description:
Mass culture became increasingly
homogeneous in the postwar years,
inspiring challenges to conformity by artists,
intellectuals, and rebellious youth.

528546AD7536416EBCC0089FB3EBA199.description:
Explain how mass culture
has been maintained or
challenged over time.

07DBDA14468C4FB7AC481EA15A97F6D0.description:
As higher education opportunities and new
technologies rapidly expanded, increasing
social mobility encouraged the migration of
the middle class to the suburbs and of many
Americans to the South and West. The Sun Belt
region emerged as a significant political and
economic force.

213CA89D5D14487E9B5FD3E06A831FA6.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the migration of
various groups of Americans
after 1945.

DA042E58F0654D5EB1397C29EBE49D3E.description:
A burgeoning private sector, federal
spending, the baby boom, and technological
developments helped spur economic growth.

E605DCF04257468DB973A249D22BC6B2.description:
Explain the causes of
economic growth in the years
after World War II.

C5CE45145EB74278AB9A95FAB59B9BA2.description:
Americans debated policies and methods
designed to expose suspected communists
within the United States even as both
parties supported the broader strategy of
containing communism.

DE94E2D667424B7DB32EFD627EB19FE5.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the Red Scare after
World War II.

397AF8A069BB4AE1998DC92943361B6C.description:
The Cold War fluctuated between periods of
direct and indirect military confrontation and
periods of mutual coexistence (or détente).

22CBD09C11C143AF96A3C0BC4164C11E.description:
Concerned by expansionist Communist
ideology and Soviet repression, the United
States sought to contain communism through
a variety of measures, including major military
engagements in Korea.

9500CCC9635C442688CF81423A858A93.description:
As postwar tensions dissolved the wartime
alliance between Western democracies and
the Soviet Union, the United States developed
a foreign policy based on collective security,
international aid, and economic institutions
that bolstered non-Communist nations.

F0EE720189374E0084D99B8687D47464.description:
United States policymakers engaged in a cold
war with the authoritarian Soviet Union, seeking
to limit the growth of Communist military power
and ideological influence, create a free-market
global economy, and build an international
security system.

73D6D7FCB466482B8CCA51356F562BDB.description:
Explain the continuities and
changes in Cold War policies
from 1945 to 1980.

382CCB81E79243C6AB9ABA102224754F.description:
New demographic and social
developments, along with anxieties over
the Cold War, changed U.S. culture and led
to significant political and moral debates
that sharply divided the nation.

E5D544C2742E4D49AD4D1124CF3E84F5.description:
Rapid economic and social changes in
American society fostered a sense of
optimism in the postwar years.

2C694B8C6AE948479C3D7FCF950EF8C2.description:
Postwar economic and demographic changes
had far-reaching consequences for American
society, politics, and culture.

06A0F4D2B8FD4DA0836322D4C2A553B7.description:
Liberalism influenced postwar politics
and court decisions, but it came under
increasing attack from the left as well as
from a resurgent conservative movement.

0E4BDD46930F4570BD1CFE322B048159.description:
Responding to social conditions and the
African American civil rights movement,
a variety of movements emerged that
focused on issues of identity, social justice,
and the environment.

1C0FE13F4FBC4A68B84AED6757DD83E7.description:
Seeking to fulfill Reconstruction-era
promises, civil rights activists and political
leaders achieved some legal and political
successes in ending segregation, although
progress toward racial equality was slow.

CF03331DCFB544C3B0BE0240E9376F54.description:
New movements for civil rights and
liberal efforts to expand the role of
government generated a range of political
and cultural responses.

57BECC9D191844EF85AEDB1D1922642A.description:
Cold War policies led to public debates
over the power of the federal government
and acceptable means for pursuing
international and domestic goals while
protecting civil liberties.

06EC05902EC446FC938302F15B4A78E1.description:
United States policymakers engaged in
a cold war with the authoritarian Soviet
Union, seeking to limit the growth of
Communist military power and ideological
influence, create a free-market global
economy, and build an international
security system.

9F34C79A23D84D91AC7E63D3855E4E4D.description:
The United States responded to an uncertain
and unstable postwar world by asserting
and working to maintain a position of global
leadership, with far-reaching domestic and
international consequences.

04981D348AC846F9B1E1F6388BB8D0A5.description:
Explain the context for societal
change from 1945 to 1980.

F0FD753A5E1A4821BE3DB85E7B898075.description:
U.S. participation in World War II transformed
American society, while the victory of the
United States and its allies over the Axis
powers vaulted the U.S. into a position of
global, political, and military leadership.

4EFF0998130843D59ED08FA78F726FA1.description:
World War I and its aftermath intensified
ongoing debates about the nation’s role in
the world and how best to achieve national
security and pursue American interests.

8AA1FFCA7D494C388D7A59B20EBDD13F.description:
In the late 19th century and early
20th century, new U.S. territorial ambitions
and acquisitions in the Western Hemisphere
and the Pacific accompanied heightened
public debates over America’s role in
the world.

0CD37B2B5DEC4172A9B2105AA71FFBAA.description:
Participation in a series of global conflicts
propelled the United States into a position of
international power while renewing domestic
debates over the nation’s proper role in
the world.

57F08309807B447CB0D75D80F5E6CCA2.description:
Economic pressures, global events, and
political developments caused sharp
variations in the numbers, sources, and
experiences of both international and
internal migrants.

B09AFE93A46D4B87B347D9BDD951FE90.description:
Popular culture grew in influence in U.S.
society, even as debates increased over the
effects of culture on public values, morals,
and American national identity.

9CBD06F24FF84106B6A4D70B46082E50.description:
Innovations in communications and technology
contributed to the growth of mass culture,
while significant changes occurred in internal
and international migration patterns.

9090A20B2FC345099FE05B3414024764.description:
During the 1930s, policymakers responded
to the mass unemployment and social
upheavals of the Great Depression by
transforming the U.S. into a limited welfare
state, redefining the goals and ideas of
modern American liberalism.

E58663CD21164903A84C4B68A5DCBBB0.description:
In the Progressive Era of the early
20th century, Progressives responded to
political corruption, economic instability,
and social concerns by calling for greater
government action and other political and
social measures.

16B1724CB3674FACABE4A7FC62C224E1.description:
The United States continued its transition
from a rural, agricultural economy to
an urban, industrial economy led by
large companies.

6D60159F2AD046009D9B67639410FAF7.description:
Growth expanded opportunity, while economic
instability led to new efforts to reform U.S.
society and its economic system.

18F9B0DFE7B24289BEACFFA8462BD2C0.description:
Compare the relative
significance of the major
events of the first half of
the 20th century in shaping
American identity

71D2F6C3D0174357B1241F1D3A865F60.description:
The war-ravaged condition of Asia and Europe,
and the dominant U.S. role in the Allied victory
and postwar peace settlements, allowed the
United States to emerge from the war as the
most powerful nation on Earth.

804347A4124C4518B6898CB34F1EA651.description:
Explain the consequences
of U.S. involvement in World
War II.

29CAA65A50C14CFB91B0D5B88EC89DF4.description:
The United States and its allies achieved
military victory through Allied cooperation,
technological and scientific advances, the
contributions of servicemen and women, and
campaigns such as Pacific “island-hopping”
and the D-Day invasion. The use of atomic
bombs hastened the end of the war and
sparked debates about the morality of using
atomic weapons.

8921103E14024699BFF8ABD4E274051C.description:
Military service provided opportunities
for women and minorities to improve their
socioeconomic positions for the war’s
duration, while also leading to debates over
racial segregation.

F73C2EA4548643B9A8BBDAAD7D548522.description:
Americans viewed the war as a fight for
the survival of freedom and democracy
against fascist and militarist ideologies. This
perspective was later reinforced by revelations
about Japanese wartime atrocities, Nazi
concentration camps, and the Holocaust.

5F2CA6C583E2470EA6DC8CDB0E3E25C1.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the victory of the
United States and its allies
over the Axis powers.

9FC58FA955D94CD2B3089F2D8935CB33.description:
Migration to the United States from Mexico
and elsewhere in the Western Hemisphere
increased, in spite of contradictory government
policies toward Mexican immigration.

AE187C92746340B8BBD85D89982029E8.description:
Mobilization provided opportunities for women
and minorities to improve their socioeconomic
positions for the war’s duration, while also
leading to debates over racial segregation.
Wartime experiences also generated
challenges to civil liberties, such as the
internment of Japanese Americans.

73EF557471AE470CB0ED31EFFB827C69.description:
The mass mobilization of American society
helped end the Great Depression, and the
country’s strong industrial base played a
pivotal role in winning the war by equipping and
provisioning allies and millions of U.S. troops.

EB8FEE288E76497BB00E4714A73C2ABD.description:
Explain how and why U.S.
participation in World War II
transformed American society.

4D5C6388EA93404C9E8BE32DDA7F44FB.description:
In the 1930s, while many Americans were
concerned about the rise of fascism and
totalitarianism, most opposed taking military
action against the aggression of Nazi Germany
and Japan until the Japanese attack on
Pearl Harbor drew the United States into
World War II.

1E8881196E6D488EBF7D7E79D2E42ED4.description:
In the years following World War I, the United
States pursued a unilateral foreign policy that
used international investment, peace treaties,
and select military intervention to promote
a vision of international order, even while
maintaining U.S. isolationism.

E3ADC05ADC6F45BA9A290C315A904A26.description:
Explain the similarities and
differences in attitudes about
the nation’s proper role in
the world.

6B543F3C3482468F97101F5C77FD5BD9.description:
The increased demand for war production and
labor during World War II and the economic
difficulties of the 1930s led many Americans
to migrate to urban centers in search of
economic opportunities.

657D8A1B255C4D7F82703363B7AD07B2.description:
Although the New Deal did not end the
Depression, it left a legacy of reforms and
regulatory agencies and fostered a long-term
political realignment in which many ethnic
groups, African Americans, and workingclass communities identified with the
Democratic Party.

2CC190A2E8D8462EAD1CA19BABA8E61B.description:
Radical, union, and populist movements
pushed Roosevelt toward more extensive
efforts to change the American economic
system, while conservatives in Congress and
the Supreme Court sought to limit the New
Deal’s scope.

8C0A871FB4FB4D2D9FBA6463394CC6DF.description:
Franklin Roosevelt’s New Deal attempted to
end the Great Depression by using government
power to provide relief to the poor, stimulate
recovery, and reform the American economy.

954EDA2DC8C1463F9FD0D3A7A36658E9.description:
Explain how the Great
Depression and the New Deal
impacted American political,
social, and economic life
over time.

F5BA174109394E6690B5045E0F34756A.description:
During the 1930s, policymakers responded to
the mass unemployment and social upheavals
of the Great Depression by transforming the
U.S. into a limited welfare state, redefining the
goals and ideas of modern American liberalism.

0B39FF23A33D4F49A7A6208CA3EAFCD6.description:
Episodes of credit and market instability in
the early 20th century, in particular the Great
Depression, led to calls for a stronger financial
regulatory system.

E245B0D4A50A434494765CB32403FE92.description:
Explain the causes of the
Great Depression and its
effects on the economy.

96D39D2C975B4A0C85C5CAC6B3188D57.description:
In the 1920s, cultural and political
controversies emerged as Americans debated
gender roles, modernism, science, religion, and
issues related to race and immigration.

0FAED287BF4A4AE88158AED469332989.description:
Migration gave rise to new forms of art
and literature that expressed ethnic and
regional identities, such as the Harlem
Renaissance movement.

DBB00EFB8B6849768E0529F646D2E49E.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of developments in
popular culture in the United
States over time.

A8F7551AAB7740FCA767276B3D2FB5B6.description:
After World War I, nativist campaigns against
some ethnic groups led to the passage of
quotas that restricted immigration, particularly
from southern and eastern Europe, and
increased barriers to Asian immigration.

2BD59846D2F640E18E86EFA75F71CC53.description:
By 1920, a majority of the U.S. population lived
in urban centers, which offered new economic
opportunities for women, international
migrants, and internal migrants.

D1EE4366A48C4B4ABF469EEB339C34CD.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of international and
internal migration patterns
over time.

5D1B20E4FE4A4F5E9BB41D9CE5C09480.description:
New forms of mass media, such as radio and
cinema, contributed to the spread of national
culture as well as greater awareness of
regional cultures.

03D2F43FA486437C972394D0E5ABC19D.description:
New technologies and manufacturing
techniques helped focus the U.S. economy
on the production of consumer goods,
contributing to improved standards of
living, greater personal mobility, and better
communications systems.

4464E5F90C6343A68F6A3C9138F36814.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the innovations
in communication and
technology in the United
States over time.

D0F54BA7BA324B529C57C62D4BF5BD0B.description:
In the Great Migration during and after World
War I, African Americans escaping segregation,
racial violence, and limited economic
opportunity in the South moved to the North
and West, where they found new opportunities
but still encountered discrimination.

66C9BF27B068498D8C2EFC711EE0DF9D.description:
The increased demand for war production and
labor during World War I led many Americans
to migrate to urban centers in search of
economic opportunities.

9EDD4CC5C6414CFBB5A721E34533C4FF.description:
Immigration from Europe reached its peak in
the years before World War I. During World
War I, nativist campaigns against some
ethnic groups led to the passage of quotas
that restricted immigration, particularly from
southern and eastern Europe, and increased
barriers to Asian immigration.

EBE7326BDEF04FC0848B17AB1AE6EAF6.description:
Official restrictions on freedom of speech grew
during World War I, as increased anxiety about
radicalism led to a Red Scare and attacks on
labor activism and immigrant culture.

A78E42BF686D4A2BA76F8B7DB60E228F.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of international and
internal migration patterns
over time.

ABBB5280A86E4034914D1C4794EAA21A.description:
Despite Wilson’s deep involvement in postwar
negotiations, the U.S. Senate refused to ratify
the Treaty of Versailles or join the League
of Nations.

BB8D8690BCF34CD08E18C4A9FEE74BC9.description:
Although the American Expeditionary Forces
played a relatively limited role in combat, the
United States’ entry helped to tip the balance
of the conflict in favor of the Allies.

027111A6F5FC413AA73143943E45E78F.description:
After initial neutrality in World War I, the nation
entered the conflict, departing from the U.S.
foreign policy tradition of noninvolvement in
European affairs, in response to Woodrow
Wilson’s call for the defense of humanitarian
and democratic principles.

BEC69F3B86644C23B2AF0BDB45B883B3.description:
Explain the causes and
consequences of U.S.
involvement in World War I.

2E7EBE26151B4BABA310E317EC4D1049.description:
World War I:
Military and Diplomacy

31DF276031154DB38C519B3011EE7B53.description:
Preservationists and conservationists both
supported the establishment of national
parks while advocating different government
responses to the overuse of natural resources.

EC116B2947C14F1BBBF1EEEFDB87D3F1.description:
Compare attitudes toward
the use of natural resources
from 1890 to 1945.

3FE0538943E248589CB1832EBC06206D.description:
On the national level, Progressives sought
federal legislation that they believed would
effectively regulate the economy, expand
democracy, and generate moral reform.
Progressive amendments to the Constitution
dealt with issues such as prohibition and
women’s suffrage.

3CB1A07026BF461FBD7BBC10F6F976CC.description:
The Progressives were divided over many
issues. Some Progressives supported
Southern segregation, while others ignored
its presence. Some Progressives advocated
expanding popular participation in government,
while others called for greater reliance on
professional and technical experts to make
government more efficient. Progressives also
disagreed about immigration restriction.

B7894AE1307045D4B2D8AD410D2045CD.description:
Some Progressive Era journalists attacked
what they saw as political corruption, social
injustice, and economic inequality, while
reformers, often from the middle and upper
classes and including many women, worked
to effect social changes in cities and among
immigrant populations.

5EB3695FD03042B6AE7FC76FC4BD266B.description:
Compare the goals and
effects of the Progressive
reform movement.

0ED508E503354988B8405DB9BA1585F3.description:
The American victory in the Spanish–American
War led to the U.S. acquisition of island
territories in the Caribbean and the Pacific,
an increase in involvement in Asia, and the
suppression of a nationalist movement in
the Philippines.

2A6ABACDD48940EE9C0A636A99CE79E7.description:
Explain the effects of the
Spanish–American War.

B39E3074082849CEB866A89A85150D63.description:
Anti-imperialists cited principles of
self-determination and invoked both racial
theories and the U.S. foreign policy tradition
of isolationism to argue that the United States
should not extend its territory overseas.

0FE2D0970ABB490F9FE56341846E1371.description:
Imperialists cited economic opportunities,
racial theories, competition with European
empires, and the perception in the 1890s that
the western frontier was “closed” to argue
that Americans were destined to expand their
culture and institutions to peoples around
the globe.

8B3E46080CDB443D903C25A7D65AAABC.description:
Explain the similarities and
differences in attitudes about
the nation’s proper role in
the world.

6EAC75FA1AB04DBEB6FFA3F40D7F7CF0.description:
U.S. participation in World War II transformed
American society, while the victory of the
United States and its allies over the Axis
powers vaulted the U.S. into a position of
global, political, and military leadership.

6BDCC8B9023D46A2BA9ED2C95ED27904.description:
World War I and its aftermath intensified
ongoing debates about the nation’s role in
the world and how best to achieve national
security and pursue American interests.

C42AEB23F1494F3CAAEE12FCFE89D8BE.description:
In the late 19th century and early
20th century, new U.S. territorial ambitions
and acquisitions in the Western Hemisphere
and the Pacific accompanied heightened
public debates over America’s role in
the world.

5E0E04AD089547058161F17232BEAF46.description:
Participation in a series of global conflicts
propelled the United States into a position of
international power while renewing domestic
debates over the nation’s proper role in
the world.

4BA1E4E6ACD249B4AD8AB0F91A44293D.description:
Economic pressures, global events, and
political developments caused sharp
variations in the numbers, sources, and
experiences of both international and
internal migrants.

E2FE32E00C114279A7C2BAB0DD25AAED.description:
Popular culture grew in influence in U.S.
society, even as debates increased over the
effects of culture on public values, morals,
and American national identity.

8C343ECDCE2243669687062876C2A088.description:
Innovations in communications and technology
contributed to the growth of mass culture,
while significant changes occurred in internal
and international migration patterns.

7A31FB805F4144C6829C1072FE1BA0C4.description:
During the 1930s, policymakers responded
to the mass unemployment and social
upheavals of the Great Depression by
transforming the U.S. into a limited welfare
state, redefining the goals and ideas of
modern American liberalism.

5F0E283898A043E4A4B1BC8BB083DAC1.description:
In the Progressive Era of the early
20th century, Progressives responded to
political corruption, economic instability,
and social concerns by calling for greater
government action and other political and
social measures.

57C5A6BAF71B41DC966C022FB9B553E2.description:
Growth expanded opportunity, while economic
instability led to new efforts to reform U.S.
society and its economic system.

868B9A375C1B4F3DB442B8B6C3ED4474.description:
Explain the context in which
America grew into its role as
a world power.

4FC2076B66B241D299AB198BC1C0A402.description:
Dramatic social changes in the period
inspired political debates over citizenship,
corruption, and the proper relationship
between business and government.

54DB21330B2440EAB07CC4AC714ED2E4.description:
New cultural and intellectual movements
both buttressed and challenged the social
order of the Gilded Age.

F76D8A986DCA452A84251943CDF80315.description:
The Gilded Age produced new cultural and
intellectual movements, public reform efforts,
and political debates over economic and
social policies.

3BFE57C2C9114A98A740935C0AAFCFBE.description:
Larger numbers of migrants moved to
the West in search of land and economic
opportunity, frequently provoking
competition and violent conflict.

B3FC8A31FCC24757BDB99E41A4D2A579.description:
International and internal migration
increased urban populations and fostered
the growth of a new urban culture.

87EAB1D2254F4BBA831FEFEDD57805E1.description:
The migrations that accompanied
industrialization transformed both urban and
rural areas of the United States and caused
dramatic social and cultural change.

F4850EF82F9C4DA9A6EEC3666833CD7C.description:
New systems of production and
transportation enabled consolidation within
agriculture, which, along with periods of
instability, spurred a variety of responses
from farmers.

66AC51B523A6432882F226F3BDA215C4.description:
A variety of perspectives on the economy
and labor developed during a time of
financial panics and downturns.

3FF04BE8F67A48DAA21D65E3287D6370.description:
Large-scale industrial production—
accompanied by massive technological
change, expanding international
communication networks, and pro-growth
government policies—generated
rapid economic development and
business consolidation.

CC5B197CFFCA4D52B0FACA5829C0BA2F.description:
Technological advances, large-scale
production methods, and the opening of new
markets encouraged the rise of industrial
capitalism in the United States.

4A2768DAE4204D41A970CC9642003CB0.description:
Explain the extent to which
industrialization brought
change from 1865 to 1898.

F4D4015EDF684C96A9DDCE1843F07C25.description:
In an urban atmosphere where the access
to power was unequally distributed, political
machines thrived, in part by providing
immigrants and the poor with social services.

335E92F4ADA54AB4A9356DD3B0D4A75B.description:
The major political parties appealed to lingering
divisions from the Civil War and contended over
tariffs and currency issues, even as reformers
argued that economic greed and self-interest
had corrupted all levels of government.

F6CE4D1F5B314681B8EEAFCE4741D5AB.description:
Economic instability inspired agrarian activists
to create the People’s (Populist) Party, which
called for a stronger governmental role in
regulating the American economic system.

F0661F3B4DEF4BDB8AAEC07CDC4A0374.description:
Explain the similarities and
differences between the
political parties during the
Gilded Age.

B258BDDBFA564A7985DFFAF65B8E0C39.description:
Foreign policymakers increasingly looked
outside U.S. borders in an effort to gain
greater influence and control over markets
and natural resources in the Pacific Rim,
Asia, and Latin America.

0324F6E1CCB44755BFA2D89F98F4704C.description:
Some argued that laissez-faire policies and
competition promoted economic growth in
the long run, and they opposed government
intervention during economic downturns.

CC7CEA600EC94E328F1931619A475D50.description:
Explain continuities and
changes in the role of
the government in the
U.S. economy

A7A8EFF3FC4941F5BC0999612EFC6677.description:
Controversies over the
Role of Government
in the Gilded Age

BEBE4D0FCEB14E518DB2C6941BE8D990.description:
Many women sought greater equality with
men, often joining voluntary organizations,
going to college, and promoting social and
political reform.

AEAC879987844EE6A28A0E18B55D1F80.description:
A number of artists and critics, including
agrarians, utopians, socialists, and advocates
of the Social Gospel, championed alternative
visions for the economy and U.S. society.

50CC646BFD664111AC62A2097DAE6E1D.description:
Explain how different reform
movements responded to the
rise of industrial capitalism in
the Gilded Age.

BD9032379DE647BA94F7D690FFD8E5C2.description:
Some business leaders argued that the
wealthy had a moral obligation to help the less
fortunate and improve society, as articulated
in the idea known as the Gospel of Wealth,
and they made philanthropic contributions
that enhanced educational opportunities and
urban environments.

02D6F11B817A4B609A48530234AD95D8.description:
Corporations’ need for managers and for
male and female clerical workers, as well as
increased access to educational institutions,
fostered the growth of a distinctive middle
class. A growing amount of leisure time also
helped expand consumer culture.

09A239862C6B477290A3B365CAEDC53D.description:
Explain the causes of
increased economic
opportunity and its effects
on society.

4AD09530F0F84977976A01DEA7DACE2D.description:
Many women, like Jane Addams, worked in
settlement houses to help immigrants adapt to
U.S. language and customs.

079F3486AF1E4775B790BD7A8B8FAF15.description:
Social commentators advocated theories
later described as Social Darwinism to
justify the success of those at the top of the
socioeconomic structure as both appropriate
and inevitable.

C5211E8D162D418E94CCFCFBFB744D93.description:
Increasing public debates over assimilation
and Americanization accompanied the growth
of international migration. Many immigrants
negotiated compromises between the cultures
they brought and the culture they found in the
United States.

89B165150054441FAEEE2EBFD9738D35.description:
Explain the various responses
to immigration in the period
over time.

F8A1944175BF46D093696086FF810037.description:
Responses to
Immigration in
the Gilded Age

C00E56433E3547EB8DF589D298F7E1A4.description:
Urban neighborhoods based on particular
ethnicities, races, and classes provided new
cultural opportunities for city dwellers.

26CDADDED6514C77AC65786599BFAD6A.description:
As cities became areas of economic growth
featuring new factories and businesses, they
attracted immigrants from Asia and southern
and eastern Europe, as well as African American
migrants within and out of the South. Many
migrants moved to escape poverty, religious
persecution, and limited opportunities for social
mobility in their home countries or regions.

68BE8073EE944CA9B9527C5CA4A6FD26.description:
The industrial workforce expanded and
became more diverse through internal and
international migration.

72B59FB2AF1D4B6D8889042C409DEDBA.description:
Explain how cultural and
economic factors affected
migration patterns over time.

1AFC9718DE2D4ABEBDC8D127A1BC2D8F.description:
Immigration and
Migration in the
Gilded Age

C4827066A2694F9FA166A62841DC92CD.description:
The industrial workforce expanded and child
labor increased.

CA0791BA0A5948B4A01DA04E4C572CFD.description:
Labor and management battled over wages
and working conditions, with workers
organizing local and national unions and/or
directly confronting business leaders.

16EE986362324F15B108055FCAA2AB7D.description:
As the price of many goods decreased,
workers’ real wages increased, providing new
access to a variety of goods and services;
many Americans’ standards of living improved,
while the gap between rich and poor grew.

0A97FA9606DD4EE2A2B9E31742BD124A.description:
Explain the socioeconomic
continuities and changes
associated with the growth
of industrial capitalism from
1865 to 1898.

AB1C1D1C334D4FA48AFD522292817532.description:
Businesses increasingly looked outside U.S.
borders in an effort to gain greater influence
and control over markets and natural resources
in the Pacific Rim, Asia, and Latin America.

01B17EBCFE964D99B234EADFD90F05E5.description:
Many business leaders sought increased
profits by consolidating corporations into large
trusts and holding companies, which further
concentrated wealth.

2E09CA4502B746D7B90FAC19AA0B2AEA.description:
Businesses made use of redesigned financial
and management structures, advances
in marketing, and a growing labor force to
dramatically increase the production of goods.

9446FA7C69424C1390C15164CABC1E7E.description:
Large-scale industrial production—
accompanied by massive technological
change, expanding international
communication networks, pro-growth
government policies—generated rapid
economic development and business
consolidation.

FD107931997940419F04FB2F9080BC3A.description:
Explain the socioeconomic
continuities and changes
associated with the growth
of industrial capitalism from
1865 to 1898.

0CECC0E5D7D34968A397B62510B49D9E.description:
Businesses made use of technological
innovations and greater access to natural
resources to dramatically increase the
production of goods.

17DD5B958B354755A034AD6BEDCE5180.description:
Explain the effects of
technological advances
in the development of the
United States over time.

3C57E37CB07A483A983FF778AFC8FCF3.description:
The Supreme Court decision in Plessy v.
Ferguson that upheld racial segregation
(known as Jim Crow) helped to mark the end of
most of the political gains African Americans
made during Reconstruction. Facing increased
violence, discrimination, and scientific theories
of race, African American reformers continued
to fight for political and social equality

ED5041DB5428418BB93BD6560EC949C0.description:
Despite the industrialization of some segments
of the Southern economy—a change promoted
by Southern leaders who called for a “New
South”—agriculture based on sharecropping
and tenant farming continued to be the primary
economic activity in the South.

8C9019D1463E446CABD29302B9D95011.description:
Explain how various factors
contributed to continuity and
change in the “New South”
from 1877 to 1898.

5CDF29B816E64768A87152D4C05FD9D1.description:
Many American Indians preserved their
cultures and tribal identities despite
government policies promoting assimilation,
and they attempted to develop self-sustaining
economic practices.

88846FE82FCE4D5AB637EFD4B3C9ED14.description:
The U.S. government violated treaties with
American Indians and responded to resistance
with military force, eventually confining
American Indians to reservations and denying
tribal sovereignty.

4D34C9F344CF4B619AE68D617989044D.description:
As migrant populations increased in number
and the American bison population was
decimated, competition for land and resources
in the West among white settlers, American
Indians, and Mexican Americans led to an
increase in violent conflict.

33127421BCC541D29DDBE5C679AB86DD.description:
In hopes of achieving ideals of self-sufficiency
and independence, migrants moved to both
rural and boomtown areas of the West for
opportunities, such as building the railroads,
mining, farming, and ranching.

8AE1B69EE66942988198A729DE8AD0DE.description:
Explain the causes and effects
of the settlement of the West
from 1877 to 1898.

1A9CC4DC787B4DD68CFE201C686E3963.description:
Westward Expansion:
Social and Cultural
Development

B43133E4369D46B6B7E1C44265582054.description:
The building of transcontinental railroads,
the discovery of mineral resources, and
government policies promoted economic
growth and created new communities and
centers of commercial activity.

BC71CEAB1B454A67964B80A683E0F190.description:
Following the Civil War, government subsidies
for transportation and communication systems
helped open new markets in North America.

8C202D5AE81D49B49FF16995A9D1A888.description:
Many farmers responded to the increasing
consolidation in agricultural markets and
their dependence on the evolving railroad
system by creating local and regional
cooperative organizations.

5C04DEFAF2E44147AA652B90CDEB05C4.description:
Improvements in mechanization helped
agricultural production increase substantially
and contributed to declines in food prices.

04BD9385B8F84C37AC288F9FF91B163C.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the settlement of
the West from 1877 to 1898.

55E9E24573F94E94A12FD7C6939F0B77.description:
Dramatic social changes in the period
inspired political debates over citizenship,
corruption, and the proper relationship
between business and government.

00FF261D82B24C5F898107CD548F2227.description:
New cultural and intellectual movements
both buttressed and challenged the social
order of the Gilded Age.

F4BF790EBBA945BFBCABCE9B4C58F952.description:
The Gilded Age produced new cultural and
intellectual movements, public reform efforts,
and political debates over economic and
social policies.

DBAC189F2F8446189BD07706F8A916C4.description:
Larger numbers of migrants moved to
the West in search of land and economic
opportunity, frequently provoking
competition and violent conflict.

DFADD2223E264B90B0F7879B3C958E3E.description:
International and internal migration
increased urban populations and fostered
the growth of a new urban culture.

0B589ECC8BEB4607ACAEEE49AAB27E3D.description:
The migrations that accompanied
industrialization transformed both urban and
rural areas of the United States and caused
dramatic social and cultural change.

781134853BEA42F6A524AAAB30502BB4.description:
New systems of production and
transportation enabled consolidation within
agriculture, which, along with periods of
instability, spurred a variety of responses
from farmers.

5387C48EDEDE488180CEB4367207EE60.description:
A variety of perspectives on the economy
and labor developed during a time of
financial panics and downturns.

1589E097D16645B88CC59535BA0C2FCB.description:
Large-scale industrial production—
accompanied by massive technological
change, expanding international
communication networks, and pro-growth
government policies—generated
rapid economic development and
business consolidation.

48DD9D056B4C417EA84AB9568618A7EB.description:
Technological advances, large-scale
production methods, and the opening of new
markets encouraged the rise of industrial
capitalism in the United States.

0E3EF61AF8474E4FAFFC0E670FBCB7C8.description:
Explain the historical
context for the rise of
industrial capitalism in the
United States.

AB6A83E0687F4D6199AED78D2640292E.description:
Reconstruction and the Civil War ended
slavery, altered relationships between
the states and the federal government,
and led to debates over new definitions
of citizenship, particularly regarding the
rights of African Americans, women, and
other minorities.

20E226B53AEC48169F55AF44C1ACB4EA.description:
The North’s greater manpower and
industrial resources, the leadership of
Abraham Lincoln and others, and the
decision to emancipate enslaved people
eventually led to the Union military victory
over the Confederacy in the devastating
Civil War.

8F0ABA2E87F249A1A0F211B7756A146B.description:
The Union victory in the Civil War and the
contested reconstruction of the South settled
the issues of slavery and secession, but left
unresolved many questions about the power of
the federal government and citizenship rights.

AB3C4F7DE5954EFC8D62C9A3E0CE0AE4.description:
Debates over slavery came to dominate
political discussion in the 1850s,
culminating in the bitter election of 1860
and the secession of Southern states.

C5AAA63AFA684EFEA93DFB666263F607.description:
Ideological and economic differences over
slavery produced an array of diverging
responses from Americans in the North and
the South.

C1FB99AFD6E541B3A3FC08D1B72E0F57.description:
Intensified by expansion and deepening
regional divisions, debates over slavery and
other economic, cultural, and political issues
led the nation into civil war.

6F9B9C5EEBA540FFBC29B3DA53D27BCF.description:
In the 1840s and 1850s, Americans
continued to debate questions about
rights and citizenship for various groups of
U.S. inhabitants.

C695F16AD1F344D198208A692630A9D5.description:
Popular enthusiasm for U.S. expansion,
bolstered by economic and security
interests, resulted in the acquisition of new
territories, substantial migration westward,
and new overseas initiatives.

FFBFE68F425C45D5917FBD69B255711A.description:
The United States became more connected
with the world, pursued an expansionist
foreign policy in the Western Hemisphere, and
emerged as the destination for many migrants
from other countries.

AFCD9B6BCC89493F859AB1BD53B72857.description:
Compare the relative
significance of the
effects of the Civil War on
American values.

682A46AF41A843CEA2F0438C01D28A21.description:
Segregation, violence, Supreme Court
decisions, and local political tactics
progressively stripped away African American
rights, but the 14th and 15th amendments
eventually became the basis for court
decisions upholding civil rights in the
20th century.

5B13916EAB834642B36512063F0C3C6C.description:
Southern plantation owners continued to own
the majority of the region’s land even after
Reconstruction. Formerly enslaved persons
sought land ownership but generally fell short
of self-sufficiency, as an exploitative and
soil-intensive sharecropping system limited
blacks’ and poor whites’ access to land in
the South.

EB7470D6BA424DC4ABB1F1533B4794A2.description:
Explain how and why
Reconstruction resulted
in continuity and change
in regional and national
understandings of what it
meant to be American.

9A7F901C553F40038489884F0E03A864.description:
Efforts by radical and moderate Republicans
to change the balance of power between
Congress and the presidency and to reorder
race relations in the defeated South yielded
some short-term successes. Reconstruction
opened up political opportunities and other
leadership roles to formerly enslaved persons
but it ultimately failed, due both to determined
Southern resistance and the North’s waning
resolve.

E79EC0EBB59C4C2CB0AB821BD3F378B1.description:
The women’s rights movement was both
emboldened and divided over the 14th and
15th amendments to the Constitution.

EC5535A4683B485F90B4B7FF1802D310.description:
The 13th Amendment abolished slavery,
while the 14th and 15th amendments granted
African Americans citizenship, equal protection
under the laws, and voting rights.

AF82E295C2464A218034A407171818C7.description:
Reconstruction altered relationships between
the states and the federal government and led
to debates over new definitions of citizenship,
particularly regarding the rights of African
Americans, women, and other minorities.

B8E4A1B4C1D645908EBF9A221846015C.description:
Explain the effects of
government policy during
Reconstruction on society
from 1865 to 1877.

F8A90CD4C69141EE83A11345BBE0EEB4.description:
Lincoln sought to reunify the country and
used speeches such as the Gettysburg
Address to portray the struggle against
slavery as the fulfillment of America’s founding
democratic ideals.

9F71330D1C4B40A088602FCEE97E94A7.description:
Lincoln and most Union supporters began
the Civil War to preserve the Union, but
Lincoln’s decision to issue the Emancipation
Proclamation reframed the purpose of the
war and helped prevent the Confederacy from
gaining full diplomatic support from European
powers. Many African Americans fled southern
plantations and enlisted in the Union Army,
helping to undermine the Confederacy.

4C56D29F28204A5BB00391A9C97C4DE0.description:
Explain how Lincoln’s
leadership during the Civil
War impacted American
ideals over the course of
the war.

04171C91E534454386CACE6171F89125.description:
Government Policies
During the Civil War

411938105BCB4216A34D6B1BD3C764A8.description:
Although the Confederacy showed military
initiative and daring early in the war, the Union
ultimately succeeded due to improvements in
leadership and strategy, key victories, greater
resources, and the wartime destruction of the
South’s infrastructure.

974AA40F68044BE2BDC00F70CF303A7F.description:
Both the Union and the Confederacy mobilized
their economies and societies to wage the
war even while facing considerable home
front opposition.

43E8D8CD15B242AC8BF1A942580B514A.description:
Explain the various factors
that contributed to the Union
victory in the Civil War.

BE3F5F72FF1F475D886111B29BD92394.description:
Military Conflict
in the Civil War

54FB025A09E940158C66C6239240EFF7.description:
Abraham Lincoln’s victory on the Republicans’
free-soil platform in the presidential election of
1860 was accomplished without any Southern
electoral votes. After a series of contested
debates about secession, most slave states
voted to secede from the Union, precipitating
the Civil War.

CC1FDA25241E460CBBB497B23B9EC145.description:
Describe the effects of
Lincoln’s election.

36BA55B711024332A0D49FC2844D7549.description:
The Second Party System ended when the
issues of slavery and anti-immigrant nativism
weakened loyalties to the two major parties
and fostered the emergence of sectional
parties, most notably the Republican Party in
the North.

1ACD098BAE814D4BA6BD715ABFBD985F.description:
The courts and national leaders made a variety
of attempts to resolve the issue of slavery in
the territories, including the Kansas–Nebraska
Act, and the Dred Scott decision, but these
ultimately failed to reduce conflict.

E31B77AE7BA249A0A6749453B1C47C42.description:
Explain the political causes of
the Civil War.

F79DA489C609432EBC22A86F88F49E41.description:
Defenders of slavery based their arguments
on racial doctrines, the view that slavery was
a positive social good, and the belief that
slavery and states’ rights were protected by
the Constitution.

8F9C2AD3B2DF45F1AF454BAC7B314B0C.description:
African American and white abolitionists,
although a minority in the North, mounted
a highly visible campaign against slavery,
presenting moral arguments against the
institution, assisting escapes, and sometimes
expressing a willingness to use violence to
achieve their goals.

EAD0B6F0E7CB44E39D72F8C34EFD1108.description:
The North’s expanding manufacturing economy
relied on free labor in contrast to the Southern
economy’s dependence on enslaved labor.
Some Northerners did not object to slavery
on principle but claimed that slavery would
undermine the free labor market. As a result,
a free-soil movement arose that portrayed
the expansion of slavery as incompatible with
free labor.

F39C4B4F546C4172AA50215A2F6AE67D.description:
Explain how regional
differences related to slavery
caused tension in the years
leading up to the Civil War.

F93A04C56DBE40C28F75C54865BB3466.description:
A strongly anti-Catholic nativist movement
arose that was aimed at limiting new immigrants’
political power and cultural influence.

F82DBC6D159B4D29A328E0AF5877B4E4.description:
Substantial numbers of international migrants
continued to arrive in the United States from
Europe and Asia, mainly from Ireland and
Germany, often settling in ethnic communities
where they could preserve elements of their
languages and customs.

366229E8C6924D5D94C74A22E9DDDEE4.description:
Explain the effects of
immigration from various
parts of the world on
American culture from 1844
to 1877.

560E28453B7549568DFE826F421D3433.description:
The courts and national leaders made a variety
of attempts to resolve the issue of slavery
in the territories, including the Compromise
of 1850.

FDAD65D1E45D4ED3ADD8AD6F08DEE439.description:
The Mexican Cession led to heated
controversies over whether to allow slavery in
the newly acquired territories.

524E526C194F47039B8EFDE6258225CC.description:
Explain the similarities and
differences in how regional
attitudes affected federal
policy in the period after the
Mexican–American War.

10551DFEE3AB4EB98D7EFF02519202F8.description:
U.S. government interaction and conflict with
Mexican Americans and American Indians
increased in regions newly taken from
American Indians and Mexico, altering these
groups’ economic self-sufficiency and cultures.

D282AC4D8DF44A98B601837CE6A4AC55.description:
The United States added large territories
in the West through victory in the Mexican–
American War and diplomatic negotiations,
raising questions about the status of slavery,
American Indians, and Mexicans in the newly
acquired lands.

04033EC7EF444E9FB0939956C57BB28A.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the Mexican–
American War.

5FC2C2E55FFF47FA8166964155059615.description:
U.S. interest in expanding trade led to
economic, diplomatic, and cultural initiatives to
create more ties with Asia.

4FBF55F1F73E4230B6A0A1C879CDDEB0.description:
Westward migration was boosted during and
after the Civil War by the passage of new
legislation promoting western transportation
and economic development.

53978F992CF3421B8457FC1244E9B250.description:
Advocates of annexing western lands argued
that Manifest Destiny and the superiority of
American institutions compelled the United
States to expand its borders westward to
the Pacific Ocean; however, this frequently
provoked competition and violent conflict.

4A85EDAC2C084C308B7A20E3678E368D.description:
The desire for access to natural and mineral
resources and the hope of many settlers for
economic opportunities or religious refuge led
to an increased migration to and settlement in
the West.

D5A635464E6B461F8A60427ACE489593.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of westward
expansion from 1844
to 1877.

6170547B3C214D4EA11DCA6CE91F2EBE.description:
Reconstruction and the Civil War ended
slavery, altered relationships between
the states and the federal government,
and led to debates over new definitions
of citizenship, particularly regarding the
rights of African Americans, women, and
other minorities.

6A3C8DAFBDFE47639EF7ABFEADDF9951.description:
The North’s greater manpower and
industrial resources, the leadership of
Abraham Lincoln and others, and the
decision to emancipate enslaved people
eventually led to the Union military victory
over the Confederacy in the devastating
Civil War.

B4DF6841064547A685B804462B9D4735.description:
The Union victory in the Civil War and the
contested reconstruction of the South settled
the issues of slavery and secession, but left
unresolved many questions about the power of
the federal government and citizenship rights.

5D8E7339471F4F2F8BE3F2CB24B6B63B.description:
Debates over slavery came to dominate
political discussion in the 1850s,
culminating in the bitter election of 1860
and the secession of Southern states.

2186E3A73DCF426A9D7773D4C88B73F4.description:
Ideological and economic differences over
slavery produced an array of diverging
responses from Americans in the North and
the South.

BA884DD9DBB243EA8E60304E421CACFF.description:
Intensified by expansion and deepening
regional divisions, debates over slavery and
other economic, cultural, and political issues
led the nation into civil war.

AF61D915A95D4A7FB154D8A4C65D609A.description:
In the 1840s and 1850s, Americans
continued to debate questions about
rights and citizenship for various groups of
U.S. inhabitants.

8055D66E46DB4C1E8E90EFD2D6DCE10D.description:
Popular enthusiasm for U.S. expansion,
bolstered by economic and security
interests, resulted in the acquisition of new
territories, substantial migration westward,
and new overseas initiatives.

3CDD969D7EF54A95ABA28219DD93AF61.description:
The United States became more connected
with the world, pursued an expansionist
foreign policy in the Western Hemisphere, and
emerged as the destination for many migrants
from other countries.

93C9DA36B35444F0AF4244A186504071.description:
Explain the context in which
sectional conflict emerged
from 1844 to 1877.

A62BD3527C0948268478A53F8093ADBB.description:
The United States’ acquisition of lands in
the West gave rise to contests over the
extension of slavery into new territories.

7A20FC7CBA08461491E87B064EF19E15.description:
Struggling to create an independent global
presence, the United States sought to claim
territory throughout the North American
continent and promote foreign trade.

CBE2CC1434B6459F8E2DBD460D595F2D.description:
The U.S. interest in increasing foreign trade
and expanding its national borders shaped the
nation’s foreign policy and spurred government
and private initiatives.

B940E0B68C58409884349E767AC9DA54.description:
Economic development shaped settlement
and trade patterns, helping to unify the
nation while also encouraging the growth of
different regions.

D6C6050F950B45C79972396F95F6FD74.description:
The changes caused by the market
revolution had significant effects on U.S.
society, workers’ lives, and gender and
family relations.

3C3926FAD2F8426A9FAAD505674C83DD.description:
New transportation systems and
technologies dramatically expanded
manufacturing and agricultural production.

9F01F619F2D74D53AA7C9469640DA1A0.description:
Innovations in technology, agriculture, and
commerce powerfully accelerated the
American economy, precipitating profound
changes to U.S. society and to national and
regional identities.

A309ECA6ABA343E9B47E9613ED8ACA6D.description:
Increasing numbers of Americans, many
inspired by new religious and intellectual
movements, worked primarily outside
of government institutions to advance
their ideals.

653CBFB8F72E439DBD149E6752D6DD77.description:
While Americans embraced a new national
culture, various groups developed
distinctive cultures of their own.

E016A8D9776243A6B51B5C59E89A75C5.description:
The nation’s transition to a more participatory
democracy was achieved by expanding
suffrage from a system based on property
ownership to one based on voting by all adult
white men, and it was accompanied by the
growth of political parties.

B2A713566586438DBC3BE7F487407435.description:
The United States began to develop a modern
democracy and celebrated a new national
culture, while Americans sought to define the
nation’s democratic ideals and change their
society and institutions to match them.

8D35C1DA6D3841AA84378FFD7DD80DFA.description:
Explain the extent to which
politics, economics, and
foreign policy promoted the
development of American
identity from 1800 to 1848.

C265F08BC6804A35A9CB141D5B02D72E.description:
As overcultivation depleted arable land in the
Southeast, slaveholders began relocating their
plantations to more fertile lands west of the
Appalachians, where the institution of slavery
continued to grow.

8D79A0B1DE48411E8ED0A0FF91C2D812.description:
Southern business leaders continued to rely
on the production and export of traditional
agricultural staples, contributing to the growth
of a distinctive Southern regional identity.

0C17B0BE2AA74D2382EC35AC3DA66540.description:
In the South, although the majority of
Southerners owned no enslaved persons, most
leaders argued that slavery was part of the
Southern way of life.

91376E0044E54B5294C07D26D246975D.description:
Explain how geographic
and environmental factors
shaped the development of
the South from 1800 to 1848.

597A7989E4AE444A98C74336043467CB.description:
The Society of
the South in the
Early Republic

D33D13A5C2724A8D8A6573037EBE4D30.description:
Enslaved blacks and free African Americans
created communities and strategies to protect
their dignity and family structures, and they
joined political efforts aimed at changing
their status.

542E5A29C2044F0EB62AB4E4DAAB5C3F.description:
Antislavery efforts in the South were largely
limited to unsuccessful rebellions by enslaved
people.

36022A93FCC540F7B795D84E0D32404A.description:
Explain the continuities and
changes in the experience of
African Americans from 1800
to 1848.

83D18A34C6E349D5B99AE69354AE9167.description:
African Americans in
the Early Republic

EDAC139C47154BA983A5398FF6EC2FE3.description:
A women’s rights movement sought to
create greater equality and opportunities for
women, expressing its ideals at the Seneca
Falls Convention. Over time, arguments
emerged over whether to narrow the goals to
white women.

95A7086C29604F8CA6486472E89A9A8F.description: Antislavery movements increased in the North.

0A5F2C8144EE4BB99646ACCB5DCCD3B2.description:
Abolitionist and antislavery movements gradually
achieved emancipation in the North, contributing
to the growth of the free African American
population, even as many state governments
restricted African Americans’ rights.

E94A55092419410C95E292EB2CF57E96.description:
Americans formed new voluntary organizations
that aimed to change individual behaviors and
improve society through temperance and other
reform efforts.

B0E683F4CFCC4BA5AB292393D768D34A.description:
The rise of democratic and individualistic beliefs,
a response to rationalism, and changes to
society caused by the market revolution, along
with greater social and geographical mobility,
contributed to a Second Great Awakening
among Protestants that influenced moral and
social reforms and inspired utopian and other
religious movements.

3F291D089FFA47AD89656440930FD018.description:
Explain how and why
various reform movements
developed and expanded
from 1800 to 1848.

80A293748E2942F99DE11C317232BFC9.description:
The rise of democratic and individualistic
beliefs, a response to rationalism, and changes
to society caused by the market revolution,
along with greater social and geographical
mobility, contributed to a Second Great
Awakening among Protestants.

A534B7CC1BF242009BAC6F0922A525C6.description:
Explain the causes of the
Second Great Awakening.

E42CE25A5A6D46C5910E8355B7EE7714.description:
Liberal social ideas from abroad and Romantic
beliefs in human perfectibility influenced
literature, art, philosophy, and architecture.

B1BD9403D9BE49479B9E4B7BC562A4FD.description:
A new national culture emerged that combined
American elements, European influences, and
regional cultural sensibilities.

F9F50F4584814C44B8047D3ECA4EF514.description:
Explain how and why a new
national culture developed
from 1800 to 1848.

3A2276790FCD4F4DBA8CF642E693945C.description:
The Development of
an American Culture

ADE5AFB81C8C4E9BB44DC74DA424F6B6.description:
Frontier settlers tended to champion expansion
efforts, while American Indian resistance led to a
sequence of wars and federal efforts to control
and relocate American Indian populations.

D7FAD64FA55D4A5CA536D383C32A062A.description:
By the 1820s and 1830s, new political parties
arose—the Democrats, led by Andrew
Jackson, and the Whigs, led by Henry Clay—
that disagreed about the role and powers of
the federal government and issues such as
the national bank, tariffs, and federally funded
internal improvements.

02F3F1F5342F4C3AB3A54AC37D476B32.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of continuing policy
debates about the role of
the federal government from
1800 to 1848.

1B222EA346304294A36CBDD62DC957BD.description:
The nation’s transition to a more participatory
democracy was achieved by expanding
suffrage from a system based on property
ownership to one based on voting by all adult
white men, and it was accompanied by the
growth of political parties.

7D04B7B636DB4B718A11874924F69F84.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the expansion of
participatory democracy
from 1800 to 1848.

124FE56CF32A488A81C65C01143D3C5A.description:
Gender and family roles changed in response
to the market revolution, particularly with
the growth of definitions of domestic ideals
that emphasized the separation of public and
private spheres.

9924B913F9DF4A97BB58D3F7B92558F6.description:
Increasing numbers of Americans, especially
women and men working in factories, no longer
relied on semi-subsistence agriculture; instead
they supported themselves producing goods
for distant markets.

71E63824389E4E7996BACD3941F6D490.description:
The growth of manufacturing drove a
significant increase in prosperity and standards
of living for some; this led to the emergence of
a larger middle class and a small but wealthy
business elite, but also to a large and growing
population of laboring poor.

92E95C783A004B1AA8C141BAD87B8060.description:
Large numbers of international migrants moved
to industrializing Northern cities, while many
Americans moved west of the Appalachians,
developing thriving new communities along the
Ohio and Mississippi rivers.

DCBC639C55154C8DB87BE3576FC446AB.description:
Explain how and why
innovation in technology,
agriculture, and commerce
affected various segments of
American society over time.

809F64A4C7A34ADFA11E5E14CB8789B6.description:
Increasing Southern cotton production and
the related growth of Northern manufacturing,
banking, and shipping industries promoted
the development of national and international
commercial ties.

7E84CC449CD64D328BE233F1F5121A18.description:
Legislation and judicial systems supported the
development of roads, canals, and railroads,
which extended and enlarged markets and
helped foster regional interdependence.
Transportation networks linked the North and
Midwest more closely than they linked regions
in the South.

B6370407D0D24559B600231404A84F94.description:
Innovations including textile machinery, steam
engines, interchangeable parts, the telegraph,
and agricultural inventions increased the
efficiency of production methods.

76D11CF3EDD749D891DAD6FC32DFB7D8.description:
Entrepreneurs helped to create a market
revolution in production and commerce, in
which market relationships between producers
and consumers came to prevail as the
manufacture of goods became more organized.

269592AA573B4D4EAE555701743E5B3F.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of the innovations in
technology, agriculture, and
commerce over time.

8269918DC50049089FD244505EB4297E.description:
The U.S. government sought influence and
control over the Western Hemisphere through
a variety of means, including military actions,
American Indian removal, and diplomatic
efforts such as the Monroe Doctrine.

89045140E3D64A95A1B366183738B455.description:
Struggling to create an independent global
presence, the United States sought to claim
territory throughout the North American
continent and promote foreign trade.

BE9F362F2CB7479DAC8029DF119A41F6.description:
Explain how and why
American foreign policy
developed and expanded
over time.

6608A79D6ED3423DA6799D7B4E629AC5.description:
Congressional attempts at political
compromise, such as the Missouri
Compromise, only temporarily stemmed
growing tensions between opponents and
defenders of slavery.

59934CAEA1834FE3BBFCE91E17501DEB.description:
Plans to further unify the U.S. economy, such as
the American System, generated debates over
whether such policies would benefit agriculture
or industry, potentially favoring different
sections of the country.

95CB4124F86E42319CA36BA1E24B710F.description:
Regional interests often trumped national
concerns as the basis for many political leaders’
positions on slavery and economic policy.

6AA89F079AA840FFB58B536AB539040B.description:
Explain how different
regional interests affected
debates about the role of the
federal government in the
early republic.

44E4B2A3DCB84BD6BF8094D447C9301D.description:
Following the Louisiana Purchase, the U.S.
government sought influence and control over
North America through a variety of means,
including exploration and diplomatic efforts.

778C21360EAB4AB89384F0158E25F6FF.description:
Supreme Court decisions established the
primacy of the judiciary in determining the
meaning of the Constitution and asserted that
federal laws took precedence over state laws.

40C253E75E50450091F9BAD45EE111C6.description:
In the early 1800s, national political parties
continued to debate issues such as the
tariff, powers of the federal government, and
relations with European powers.

DD989DC9747649E9A766FED6B892AF16.description:
Explain the causes and
effects of policy debates in
the early republic.

52B0845D0609462985FEA96D1379E789.description:
The Rise of Political
Parties and the
Era of Jefferson

CB6D938FB34F40EA9E550FD00A1FA480.description:
The United States’ acquisition of lands in
the West gave rise to contests over the
